title: Print, Muzykal'naia nov' (Musical New Land) , No. 4, 1924
provenance: Merrill Berman to Cooper Hewitt, December 2014
description: Bold design in red and black on white.  A black circle with Musykal'naia in white wrapping around a white circle with Nov in red.  This field is separated by a black bar from a lower rectangular field with 1924 in black, a central section (to be completed) and N 4, a black bar separates another field which says Moskva in black at left;   in red  at center; and   in black at right.
justification: While trained as a painter, Liubov Popova abandoned her painting career in 1921 for art that served the people and the communist State.  Strongly influenced by Kasimir Malevich and Alexandr Rodchenko, she applied a Constructivist aesthetic to her posters and other printed ephemera, textiles, stage design, clothing and ceramics.   Presented here is an issue of the Russian avant-garde journal, Muzykal’naia nov’ (Musical New Land), no. 4, 1924, with a cover by Popova.   This is a powerful graphic whose boldness and central focus approaches graphic designs of Rodchenko.  The Musical New Land journal is relatively rare, since only 1500 copies were printed.

tombstone.epitaph:
Print, Muzykal'naia nov' (Musical New Land) , No. 4, 1924. Letterpress on paper. 
Gift of Merrill C. Berman. 2014-45-1.
